4493729/4414735/4528426.title: Local History
4493729/4414735/4528426.text:
After Eoghan Roe ONeill died in 1649 the Ulster Irish army were left without a leader.  There were two many oNeills in it and if one of them were chosen to be leader they others would be jealous so that none of them could be leader. Bishop Heber MacMahon was chosen  to be their leader at last. He marched from Enniskellen till he came to Ballybofey and he
(continues on next page)

4922267/4865784/5055506.title: Story
4922267/4865784/5055506.text: "Glounaneve" is a farm quite near where I live. It is said that Owen Roe O'Neill fought a battle there in olden days. A double ditch can be seen at the present day, which served as a trench and there is a quarry in the centre of this field and it is thought that Owen Roe's soldiers were buried there also or at the "bush" of Duhill. A lady was fleeing from the enemy, and could take it no further than "Glounaneve". Some people say that soldiers can be seen riding on white horses about the field at midnight.
4922267/4865784/5055506.school_info: School: Caisleán Grás, Cloichín an Mhargaidh

5044818/5041378/5083635.title: Hidden Treasure
5044818/5041378/5083635.text: Hidden TreasureWritte by Rosena Hannigan Cullenbra (Castletara Cavan)Collected from Edward Hannigan Cullenbra Castletara CavanThere is a Treasure hidden in the townland of Drumhome Ballyhaise. It is supposed to be a barl of silver and a barl of gold. It is on the top of a hill at a castle. It is supposed to be rold into the tunl.It was Owan Roe O Neills castle and Treasure. He hid the gold and silver because the English was going to confiscate his land.One day Tom Roake ? went to look for it. He got a cart of breks from the mouth of the tunl. He could not go any further with water.

5044794/5038925/5085277.title: Cromwell
5044794/5038925/5085277.text:
(continued from previous page)
Nuair a tháinig siad go dtí an doras an ceathramadh uair bhí an choinneal múchta is an sagart ar iarraidh. Tásc nó tuairisg de ní raibh le fághail. Tháinig an Mhaighdean Mhuire i gcabhair dó agus bhí rian a láimhe le feiceál ar chúl na cathaoireach sa seomra. An mhaidin in a dhiaidh sin fuarthas i séipéal é is é a' léigheamh Aifrinn.



Many years ago there was a battle between Owen Roe O' Neil's army and the English on the borders of Glangevlin and Killinagh on Hugh Mac Manus's fort in the townland of Derylahan  The armies retreated to Lough Mac Dolan and they also fought there. The English forces were on the far side and Logan Roe was on the *Toam side. It was that fighting which caused the heights now to be seen and the shells cut the hills thus making valleys. Both the armies fought for two or three months and in the end Logan had no support for is army but one bullock. The English army had about one hundred of the same kind of animals. Logan tried a plan to get them. He took the remaining bullock to a little wood and tied him to a tree. Then he covered him with straw and set fire to it. The bullock on feeling
(continues on next page)

5044794/5038926/5085285.title: (no title)
5044794/5038926/5085285.text:
(continued from previous page)
the heat from the fire commenced to roar, thus attracting the attention of the bullocks on the far side. When they heard their comrades roar, off they went to release him. They swam the lake and never stopped till they reached Owen Roe, and when Logan saw they were all safe he took possession of them, beat the English army and also starved them. It is said that it was from Lough Mac Dolan that the two armies set out for Limerick.* Toam was the name given to the Blacklion side.



Barney Dolan as Gablhann Cillineach   was in McGrail's tailors in Doobally learning his measure for a new suit of clothes. He waited pretty late and on returning home he had to pass Hugh Mac Manus's fort in Derrylahan. As he went past it an old woman stepped out and said to him '' you are coming from the tailors Barney and you'll have your suit of clothes for our wedding in a fortnights time and you will walk in the footsteps of Logan Roe. '' That's all right '' said
(continues on next page)

4921782/4906719/5178003.title: A Funny Story - Eoghan Rua agus an Sagart
4921782/4906719/5178003.text:
I ndeire a shaoghail is amhlaidh a bhíodh Eoghan Ruadh ag siubhal o thig go tig agus ag deanamh ranna filíochta. Níor thaithn Éoghan leis na sagairt agus níor thaithn na sagairt le h-Éoghan. Lá amháin chuaidh sé cun Aifrinn. Bhí fear ag doras an tséipéil, agus bosca aige agus ní leógfadh sé aoinne isteach gan pingin a chur sa bhosca Do thárla ná raibh aon airgead ag Éoghan agus níor leogadh isteach é. Bhí cruach mhóna ar agaidh an t-séipéil amach agus do luigh Éoghan as a dhrom ann, is dubhairt ós árd - "Más mar na sagairt seo atá an tAthair MacNíl brígh 'nár ngnó'S ní fearra shúinn an t-AifrionnNá suighe ar a mhóin."
(continues on next page)

4921798/4908237/5180841.title: (no title)
4921798/4908237/5180841.text:
Nearly two-hundred years ago Owen Roe O'Sullivan worked for a farmer in this district. The famer's name was Seán Roe Hasset.This farmer had a foxy sow and there was a Cromwellian in the neighbourhood named Norket who had a famous imported red boar.The farmer said to Owen that he would ask Norket for the service of the boar but he feared that perhaps he would shoot him. In those days the Catholics were very much oppressed.Owen said that it would be all right and that he would take the sow. The night before he made up a bit of a rhyme in which to address Norket
(continues on next page)

4921798/4908239/5180843.title: (no title)
4921798/4908239/5180843.text: Owen Róe taugth a class in Annagh. He taught the Rev. Larence O'Mahony who lived to a very great age and  was buried in Buttevant Church.Own-Róe O'Sullivan died a young man and it is said it was from a blow of a tongs or a frying-pan which he got out in Kerry near where he was born.

4921814/4895037/5189306.title: Teistiméireacht Eoghain Ruaidh
4921814/4895037/5189306.text:
Bhí fear i gCiarraidhe in aimsir Eóghain Ruaidh. Spriúnlóir críochnuighthe do b'eadh é, agus do pósadh é le mnaoi caoin cneasta. Níor réidhtigeadar le chéile in aon chor, mar 'sé rud a déarfadh an fear i gcómhnuidhe ná go raibh sí ag ithe an iomarea. Uaireanta do bhuaileadh sé í le bata trom, agus i ndeire na dála d'imthigh sí ar Shlighe na Fírinne, mar bhí a croidhe briste.    Do pósadh an ath-uair é agus do b'é an sgeal ceudna é. Níor mhair sí ró fhada mar bhíodh sé i gcomnuidhe ag aighneas agus ag aragóint.Nuair a bhí sé le pósadh an thríomhadh uair dubhairt an sagart paróiste leis go gcaithfeadh sé teistiméaracht d'fághail ó athracha na mban sar a dtabharfadh sé aon bhean eile dó.   Bhí fhios ag an spriúnlóir cad do bhí in ann dó ní raibh aon deagh fhocal ag na fearaibh dó, agus bhí sé i gcruadh cás. Ní raibh fhios aige cad ba cheart dó a dhéanamh. Lá amháin do bhuail Eóghan Ruadh leis. Do nocht sé an sgéal dó. Arsa Eoghan leis:- "Scríobhfad-sa an teistiméaracht duit ar aon chiongíoll amháin." "Cad é féin" arsa Risteárd, an fear. "Mhuise ní mór é an coingeall - piúnt uisce beatha a thabhairt dom." Níor thaithn san leis an spriúnlóir, agus dubhairt sé na féadfadh sé é. Ní dubhairt Eoghan Ruadh 'seadh na ní h-eadh
(continues on next page)
